body.p: Libraries Need Aid State Aid for libraries is an annual fund appropriated by the state and used to supplement local funds to establish public libraries in areas now without them and to extend and im- prove the service of existing libraries Why Wisconsin libraries need state aid: 30 per cent of the population of the entire state is without local public library service. 40 per cent of the population, excluding Milwaukee county, has no lo- cal library service. A large proportion of the population which now has access to libraries is poorly served because the cost of adequate library service is more than some communities can support. $.44 a year is the average per capita expenditure for library service in Wisconsin from local appropriations. The minimum national standard is $1. Wisconsinâ€™s expenditure is more than 50 per cent below standard. Libraries are of primary importance in all adult education programs and provide the only free source of material for those who continue to study after leaving school. Libraries are an integral part of the educational system and arguments which support state aid for schools are equally applicable for library aid. What state aid will do for Wisconsin libraries: It will stimulate the establishment and growth of local libraries, thereby decreasing the percentage of people lacking access to the free use of books. It will tend to equalise library sup- port in leas prosperous areas without decreasing support in communities now sewed.
